title: 110_s2753
content: The Credit Card Reform Act of 2008, also known as the "Protection of Young Consumers from Prescreened Credit Offers," aims to safeguard young consumers from unsolicited credit offers. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for consumers aged 21 or older, with an option for those at least 18 years old to authorize inclusion in a list of names provided by the agency. Additionally, there is an opt-in option for young consumers in the Act. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow consumers aged 18 to 20 to opt-in to have their information included in lists provided by consumer reporting agencies for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by them. The amendment allows consumers aged 18 to 20 to opt-in to have their information included in lists provided by consumer reporting agencies for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by them, with the election being in writing and effective until the consumer's 21st birthday or a specified date. The consumer can notify the agency to revoke the election to be included in a list, and the rule of construction clarifies that individuals aged 21 or older can still opt out after turning 21. Upon turning 21, individuals can still choose to opt out of being included in a list by notifying the agency. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON UNILATERAL CHANGES IN CREDIT CARD AGREEMENTS. Chapter 4 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include a new section 171, which prohibits credit card issuers from making unilateral changes to credit card agreements before the contract expiration or renewal date. Issuers must disclose all amendments and changes to cardholders as required by law. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits credit card issuers from making unilateral changes to credit card agreements before the contract expiration or renewal date. Cardholders have the right to repay all existing balances on a credit card account that is terminated or expires. Termination of an account due to refusal to renew or failure to agree to a change in terms does not constitute a default or trigger immediate repayment obligations. Changes in disclosures prior to renewal are required under section 127(d) of the Act. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits credit card issuers from making unilateral changes to credit card agreements before the contract expiration or renewal date. Cardholders have the right to repay all existing balances on a credit card account that is terminated or expires. Changes in disclosures prior to renewal are required under section 127(d) of the Act, including any changes or amendments in the terms of the consumer's credit or charge card contract or agreement since the previous scheduled renewal date. The Truth in Lending Act requires disclosures of changes to credit card agreements before renewal date. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 4 of the Act. SEC. 4. STOPPING UNFAIR INTEREST RATES AND FEES. Prohibition on unilateral changes in credit card agreements. Section 163 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include limits on interest rate increases for credit card accounts under an open end consumer credit plan. The creditor cannot increase any annual percentage rate, fee, or finance charge before the scheduled renewal date of the plan, unless certain conditions are met. The Truth in Lending Act limits interest rate increases for credit card accounts under an open end consumer credit plan. Increases can only occur after the expiration of an introductory rate, application of a disclosed variable rate, or imposition of a penalty rate for specific consumer violations. The Truth in Lending Act restricts interest rate hikes on credit card accounts, allowing increases only after introductory rate expiration, application of disclosed variable rate, or penalty rate for consumer violations. Penalty interest rate cannot exceed 7 percentage points above the existing rate. The Truth in Lending Act limits interest rate increases on credit card accounts, only allowing hikes after introductory rate expiration, application of disclosed variable rate, or penalty rate for consumer violations. Any increased rate applies only to new credit extensions made after the increase, not retroactively to existing credit extensions. SEC. 5. CAP ON FEES CHARGED BY CREDITORS. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include limitations on late payment fees for credit card accounts under open end consumer credit plans. Credit card issuers must clearly state the payment due date on billing statements to avoid imposing late payment fees. The Truth in Lending Act now limits late payment fees for credit card accounts under open end consumer credit plans. Card issuers must specify the payment due date to avoid late fees. No late payment fee can be imposed if payment is made on or before the due date. The Truth in Lending Act limits credit card issuer fees related to defaults, omissions, or violations to costs incurred. The Board will create regulations for this limitation. A conforming amendment removes a section from the Act. SEC. 6. VERIFICATION OF ABILITY TO PAY CREDIT OBLIGATIONS. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to require credit card issuers to verify a consumer's ability to pay before opening a new account or increasing credit limits. This includes considering the consumer's income, obligations, and employment status. The Board will establish regulations for determining this ability to pay. The Board will prohibit unfair, deceptive, or evasive acts related to credit card accounts under open-end consumer credit plans. Additionally, they will ban practices associated with abusive lending or not in the consumer's interest. SEC. 7. CURBING DECEPTIVE CREDIT CARD OFFERS. Section 603(l) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to define a "firm offer of credit or insurance" as an offer that specifies all terms and will be honored if the consumer meets specific criteria based on their consumer report. The offer must disclose the annual percentage rate, fees, and credit limit. Additional conditions may apply to the offer. The consumer's eligibility for insurance may be based on verifying specific criteria from their consumer report or application, and may require collateral disclosed before the offer. The consumer's eligibility for insurance may require specific criteria verification from their consumer report or application, and collateral may need to be disclosed in the offer. The amendments made by sections 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 of this Act will take effect 6 months after enactment, with the Board of Governors for the Federal Reserve System proposing regulations to implement the amendments.
